Data Science from Scratch: First Principles with Python 2nd Edition

all_paragraphs: Data Science. It’s the sexiest job of the 21st century and everyone is talking about it. Companies are eager to hire the best talents and people are enthusiastic to jump in the data science boat. With data growing exponentially and our technology advancing at such a rapid pace, it’s no surprise that Data Science would become a fundamental job in businesses worldwide.

With data as the new oil; an immensely, untapped valuable asset, it will play an imperative role in our society. The workplace today is dominated by various specializations of Data Science positions and it has influenced business models in fundamental ways. Algorithms and formulas that run on data will replace human intuition, and data science will be the decision-maker of data-driven companies.

This sparked a hype to learn Data Science, and many have turned to the internet, a place with a plethora of resources to learn about Data Science. That said, not all of them are reliable and useful. As Data Science is surging, there are countless articles and videos — “Learn Data Science in one month” — which are misleading and superficial, a marketing strategy or “clickbait” if you will. Thus, if you intend to dig deep into what Data Science is, then you have to find the right resources to make sure you’re learning from the best.

That’s why I’ve chosen this book. If you’re someone deciding to learn Data Science, then you’re in luck. But if you’re someone already learning it or you are practicing it right now, this can be a great addition to your resource collection or refresher/test to ensure you already know Data Science from scratch.

Now you might ask, why still read books when it’s 2020? Well because reading books are still, in my opinion, the best way to learn, albeit the multifarious online courses and video tutorials flooding the internet. Here’s why:

Nevertheless, that’s not to say reading this book will magically turn you into a data scientist overnight. What’s important about learning is that you can translate your knowledge into something concrete by actually doing.

Underneath all the fancy jargon and mathematics, Data Science is just all about solving problems. And you can’t solve problems just by brainstorming solutions and reading about the quandary at hand, you need action.
So, without further ado, the book for you to start your data science journey is …

“Data Science from Scratch, 2nd Edition” is written by Joel Grus, a Data Scientist, and Analyst at startups and an engineer at Google. He got his Ph.D. from Caltech. Head over to his website to know more.

This brand-new book is the successor of the first edition of Data Science from scratch: First Principles with Python and the Python code is updated for Python 3.6, which is great since Python 2.7 has been deemed End of Life (EOL).

Throughout the book, Grus provides a simple explanation for each concept and then the rest is all code snippets, teaching you how to build popular tools and algorithms such as decision trees and neural networks from scratch. He highlights the importance of building up knowledge from the basics up to the complex theories — from the basics of Python to building Neural Networks.

To learn data science, it is key to have a profound understanding of the underlying principles and methodology of each algorithm. Anyone can build a neural network if they just followed a video tutorial, but that doesn’t mean they know what they are doing. So, one should not only master the tools — data science libraries, frameworks, modules, and toolkits — but also understand them inside out.
Data Science from Scratch has 27 chapters in total and it covers just about everything you need to know for a career in data science

1. Introduction2. A Crash Course in Python3. Visualizing Data4. Linear Algebra5. Statistics6. Probability7. Hypothesis and Inference8. Gradient Descent9. Getting Data10. Working with Data11. Machine Learning12. k-Nearest Neighbors13. Naive Bayes14. Simple Linear Regression15. Multiple Regression16. Logistic Regression17. Decision Trees18. Neural Networks19. Deep Learning20. Clustering21. Natural Language Processing22. Network Analysis23. Recommender Systems24. Databases and SQL25. MapReduce26. Data Ethics27. Go Forth and Do Data Science

Nonetheless, even if you are a complete beginner, you still can have a go on this book as long as you have the determination and will to learn.
Grus will help you get comfortable math and statistics at the core of data science, along with hacking skills you need to get started as a data scientist.

Hands down the best thing about this book is that it uses Python 3.6 as the language for all the code snippets. This is particularly useful because Python’s popularity surged in the past few years and has become one of the top languages in the programming world

Python is now the central tool for data science, an increasingly important part of computer science. With the rise of Data Science, more and more companies are utilizing their data through machine learning and AI, creating a huge demand for developers who are well versed in Python.
Thus, having the ability to code in Python will be very useful in this AI era and this book will build the foundation for you to learn Python.
While reading this book, it is encouraged to write notes while reading and highlight concepts you don’t understand very well so you can go back to it later on.

You also should have an IDE such as Pycharm + Anaconda setup or VScode so you can run the code while reading the code snippets. By doing so, you get a hands-on feel of what it’s like to work with Machine Learning algorithms give you taste of what Data Scientists do on a daily basis.
Lastly, make use of further exploration at the end of each chapter so you can go deeper into the concept yourself.
Learning Data Science is not easy. And this book surely doesn’t make it any easier. If you’re really passionate about learning, then have a go at this book.

Get your hands dirty with the code, experiment with it, digest the principles and concepts explained in the book. One way to test your understanding is by explaining what you’ve learned to your friends or colleagues in simpler terms, if they can understand you, then if it proves you’ve really understood a concept.
After reading this book, you should have a bit of knowledge of Python and a close relationship with Machine Learning algorithms. What’s next you ask?
Check out this book about manipulating, processing, cleaning, and crunching datasets in Python:
Python for Data Analysis, 2nd edition
I hope you found the article useful and managed to convince you to pick up this book and start learning Data Science.
All the best in your journey and happy learning!
